question: This is me breating.

question: He's falling for her. Look at him.
answer: He using her.

question: You're wrong. Look at his face.
answer: One cannot love and kill.

question: Marty, you haven't changed a bit!
answer: Don't say that.

question: We had pictures put on, that way everybody knows who everybody was!
answer: Wonderful.

question: So, what are you doing now?
answer: Whatever I can get away with.

question: Isn't it cute. It's so everybody knows who everybody was!
answer: Beer. Hey, Ken. How have you been?

question: Beer. Hey, Ken. How have you been?
answer: Hello Martin. How have you been?

question: Not bad. You?
answer: Hello, Bob.

question: Hey, Bob.
answer: I'm an attorney. I'm with Moss, Brice & Fromeyer.

question: That sounds pretty interesting...
answer: Sometimes. I'm in divorce, mainly. Some property. Some personal injury.

question: Those all seem kind of related... Tragedy makes you thirsty. Well... I have to take this over to Debi.
answer: Here. Take my card. Wait a minute... here's a special one. For top-shelf clients.

question: Thanks. makes his way through the upbeat crowd of well-wishers. TERRY emerges like an inkspot on a clean white whirt, and intercepts Martin. His angst is barely under control as he sidles up to Martin.
answer: I don't know, Blank, all these fucking people, driving me crazy. Look at them over there, memorializing old times, acting all like it was something "life-changing." And the people in the National Honor Society? The name tags? They have special blue starts on them like it fucking matters now that they were in the honor club ten years ago. I'm getting fucking nauseous from all this sentimental bullshit. It's making me sick.

question: Why are you here... Terry?
answer: I wanted to see a couple people. But I don't want to talk about the old days... What did we have together, Martin? Typing?

question: Drafting.
answer: Yeah, I couldn't stand that fucking class. But I appreciate you helping me out, man.

question: Don't mention it.
answer: Yeah, thanks. Well I'm going to try and get out of here, man. I'll see you later.

question: Bob. Bob Destephano.
answer: What?

question: I'm Dan. Dan Koretzky.
answer: Computer guy.

question: Yeah... Hey, I saw you at your dad's dealership the other day.
answer: I sell BMW's. What do you do?

question: Not much, actually. My software company just went public so I'm just... hanging out, really.
answer: Remember high school?

question: But wait. I still don't understand what you do.
answer: I work at Kentucky Fried Chicken.

question: You do not.
answer: Yes I do.

question: You don't...
answer: In the corporate offices.

question: Oh... really?
answer: Yeah...

question: What do you do?
answer: I sell biscuits to the Southland.

question: You do not.
answer: It's what I do.

question: You're so funny...
answer: I sell biscuits and gravy all over the Southland--

question: --Stop it--
answer: You know those horsey biscuit gravy packets? I move all of those--

question: --No.
answer: Sometimes we sell them to McDonald's and just change them to special barbecue sauce.

question: Which would you rather...?
answer: Okay... Would you rather... commit yourself sexually to a four-by-nine cell with former President George Herbert Walker Bush dressed as a super-model for a month, or make love to a otter on crank for a week?

question: Soft. I'll take the junkie otter, clearly! I'd let the little beast scratch and claw all he wants... Okay. Would you rather make love to the candied corpse of Phyllis Diller--
answer: --She's not dead---

question: It's just a game...! Alright. Candied Diller, or... wear a hot pork vest across the desert with a fully digested crab apple in your mouth?
answer: Wow. I have to give this some thought.

question: No time.
answer: Okay, then. Clearly candied Diller.

question: Thank you. Stacey, why don't you come up here and take over for a little while? Everybody thinks they know me now that I'm divorced. It's time to see you in private.
answer: Even though I left, you never left me. Not just memory but a substance in my blood.

question: Like heroin?
answer: Too junky-kitschy. Deeper, deeper.

question: Like love?
answer: Could be. The physical substance of love.

question: So. You and Debi. Gonna hit that shit again?
answer: Fine, Bob. How are you?

question: Never better.
answer: Really?

question: Ahhh... it's all fucked up. Nothing adds up to nothing... you work your whole life, day in and day out-- try to make sense of it all. One day you're twenty-seven and what do you get to show for it...
answer: You could've been a contender, huh?

question: Smart boy. Real smart. Let's see how smart you are with my foot up your ass! I'm gonna kick your ass!
answer: Why would you want to hit me, Bob? Do you really believe that there's some stored up conflict that needs resolution between us? We don't exist. There's nothing between us. So who do you want to hit, Bob? It's not me.

question: What am I gonna do?
answer: What do you want to do?

question: I want to be an actor.
answer: Then express yourself, Bob. Be honest...

question: I guess. Take care of yourself, Ken. Thanks for the pen.
answer: What the hell happened to you?

question: I was catching up with Bob Destephano.
answer: As long as you had a good time. What now? Chase the girl?

question: It didn't work out.
answer: That's too bad.

question: I have to get my head back into my work.
answer: Work's good for the soul.

question: When you see Debi, tell her I'm sorry.
answer: See you in ten years.

question: Dumb fucking luck...
answer: He was trying to kill you, right!

question: Yes.
answer: Not the other way around...?

question: No.
answer: Is it something you've done?

question: It's something I do... ...Professionally... ...About five years now.
answer: Get the fuck outta here.

question: Seriously, when I left, I joined the Army and took the service exam. They found my psych results fit a certain profile. A certain "Moral flexibility" would be the best way to describe it... I was loaned out to a CIA- sponsored program. It's called "mechanical operations." We sort of found each other...
answer: You're a government spook?

question: I was, but no... yes... I was before, but now I'm not. It's irrelevant, really. The idea of governments, nations, it's mostly a public relations theory at this point, anyway. But I'll tell you something, until about five months ago, I really enjoyed my work.
answer: Jesus Christ!

question: Then I started losing my taste for it. Which usually means your time is up. But then I realized it was something entirely different... I started getting the sneaking, dark suspicion that maybe there was... meaning to life.
answer: Okay. Great, Martin, that's just great. Meaning to life... Mmm....

question: Like, that there's a point? An organic connection between all living things.
answer: Let me help you along, Martin. You're a sociopath!

question: A sociopath kills for no reason. I kill for money.
answer: You never could have kept this from me.

question: I was leaving.
answer: That's probably a good idea.

question: Will you come with me?
answer: I'm staying here.

question: What if I come back?
answer: I'll hide.

question: Don't go.
answer: You don't get to have me. You are a monster, I'm a human being. We're not going to mate.

question: You don't understand...
answer: That's because I speak human, and you speak monster.

question: "What's up Doc? What's cookin'? What's up Doc, are you lookin'...?
answer: I'm bringing down the office now.

question: I'll put things right. Then I'll find you.
answer: Uh... why?

question: Don't worry. I left you a little something under your desk.
answer: All right!!

question: reaches the top of the front stairs to find Grocer heading up the stairs at him. They lift their guns at each other to FIRE, when they hear...
answer: heads up the back stairs.

question: works his way toward Grocer, moving with stealth toward the kitchen.
answer: hears him and starts back down. Flying through the air disappearing through the shuttered serving window, his flight carrying him past a television that sits on a lazy susan. ...How about I sell you two rounds for a hundred grand a piece?

question: Okay. There you go. I left it blank.
answer: Excellent. Here they come.

question: rises and springs at the television, gripping it. The TWO BULLETS sail past his head.
answer: begins to rise from his side of the counter, cocking his gun.

question: puts all his weight and motion behind the television. Martin and the television careen off of the counter toward Grocer.
answer: gets off one round before

question: flies onto Grocer, smashing the seventy-five pound television over his Goddamn head. Martin sails past the collision, landing on his back in the dining room. He rolls over to see
answer: Body crumpled, neck is snapped, head encased in the shattered picture tube. He is dead.
